awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: The interplay between host diet, immunity, reproduction, and the microbiome across an anthropogenic-disturbed landscape
awd_abstract_narration:
It has recently become evident that microbes within the digestive tract of an animal are not only important for digestion but also influence overall health. An animal lives with trillions of microorganisms in its body, yet the implications of having most of these microorganisms are unknown. What is known thus far has focused primarily on the importance of microorganisms for digestion. However, current work suggests that an animal's microbes have effects that extend far beyond the gut, impacting the immune system and even stress. This project seeks to understand the importance of these microorganisms for health and survival in free-living populations of endangered iguanas that are exposed to changing and unnatural diets via ecotourism. The project will test how changing microbial communities and key physiological parameters relate to reproduction and survival in natural populations. Additionally, in the laboratory the researchers will experimentally test how changes in diet, stress, and microbes affect health and physiology in order to understand what is causing the observed changes in wild iguanas. Connecting physiological and microbial changes with animal population fluctuations in nature will be an innovative step forward. Finally, understanding both the occurrence and direction of these interactions will provide important insights into the effects of human-induced diet shifts on wildlife and much needed biological knowledge regarding threatened species.  Humans have microbes in their digestive track as well, thus this project project may have broad implications on human health in relation to diet and stress. 

Many recent studies have identified significant connections between the microbiome and host health in model systems. However, mechanistic links between the microbiome and physiological functions that are key to health and survival remain mostly unexplored. Given that evolutionary history is one of the primary determinants of microbiome composition, the lack of taxonomic breadth severely restricts understanding of the physiological link between host habitat, diet, and immunity with microbiome composition and metagenomic function. There is also a paucity of research investigating microbial communities and health-related metrics within free-living animals. Thus, current knowledge of these relationships lacks critical ecological relevance and an understanding of the impact of environmental changes on endo-microbial communities. To address these current knowledge gaps, the project will study iguanas in both natural and captive settings, in order to test relationships among ecoimmune indices, anthropogenic-based diet changes, and the microbiome across a fragmented, insular landscape in The Bahamas. In the laboratory, the principal investigators will perform ecologically-relevant experimental manipulations in captive iguanas to test directional relationships in wild populations. The principal investigators will also investigate the stability of these associations over time in conjunction with a long-term mark recapture data set (37+ years) to estimate the influence of ecoimmunological, oxidative, and microbiome indices on reproductive output and survival across different populations exposed to variable human influence.

This award was co-funded by the Division of Integrative Organismal Systems, the Division of Environmental Biology, and the Rules of Life Venture Fund within The Directorate for Biological Sciences.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Organisms have evolved to function optimally in the environment in which their ancestors lived. While environmental conditions can change over time, traditionally such change occurred at a slow enough rate to enable the organism to adapt to those changes. However, human interaction with the environment, whether global (such as climate change) or local (such as urbanization or deforestation) can lead to environmental changes that occur at a much more rapid rate, threatening to disconnect the linkage between organism function and environmental conditions. While climate change is a very common and often debated human-environment interaction because of its global nature, more local human-environment interactions receive much less attention, yet they can have dramatic impacts on the well-being of local populations of animals.

Ecotourism brings considerable value to conservation, as it exposes people to the natural environment and produces local revenue. However, ecotourism also has some cautionary aspects in that it brings varying levels of disturbance to natural populations of animals. This is especially true for ecotourism activities that include feeding wildlife. Feeding animals unnatural diets can alter their behavior, growth, reproductive potential, and metabolism. It can also alter the microbial communities within their digestive tracts.

It has become evident that microbes within the digestive tract of an animal are not only important for digestion, but also influence overall health. An animal lives with trillions of microorganisms in its body, yet the implications of hosting most of these microorganisms are not well understood. What is known thus far is focused primarily on the importance of microorganisms for digestion. However, current work suggests that an animal’s microbes have effects that extend far beyond the gut, impacting the immune system and even stress. To address these current knowledge gaps, this project investigated the impact of unnatural feeding by tourists on free-living populations of endangered iguanas. This model system is ideal because of the availability of a 44-year continuous life history data set, on both tourist-visited and unvisited islands. We investigated iguanas in both natural and captive settings to test how changing microbial communities and key physiological parameters relate to reproduction and survival in natural populations. To understand causal agents for observed changes in wild iguanas. we experimentally tested how changes in diet, challenges to the immune system, and microbes affect health and physiology in the laboratory. Connecting physiological and microbial changes with fluctuations in wild animal populations is an innovative step forward.

This project resulted in significant outcomes for all of our aims. First, we found persistent tourist-driven effects on gut microbial communities including higher alpha and beta diversity in wild rock iguanas microbiomes and significantly different overall microbiome profiles associated with tourist visitation frequency. Metagenomic analyses further supported these findings with changes in metagenomics at tourist sites linked to immune and metabolic molecular networks. Likewise, we found that tourist activities are associated with significantly increased immune function, elevated energy metabolites and oxidative stress, and increased reproductive rates (i.e., reproduction rate was 3 times greater at fed versus unfed islands), but decreased baseline corticosterone (energy mobilizing hormone). These physiology measures are also correlated with a broad range of bacterial families, including those that differ among islands with different tourism levels. We are currently testing the implications of tourist-altered diets on long-term survival and fitness measures via population modeling approaches.

Second, in the lab we demonstrated that a high sugar diet leads directly to shifts in the gut microbial communities and enhances inflammatory immune components. However, following an immune challenge in green iguanas, animals on the high sugar diet had reduced bacterial killing ability and also reduced microbial diversity. In a subsequent study we found that dysbiosis (via antibiotics) that reduced key bacterial families led to elevated immune responses. We also demonstrated that glucose supplementation in the lab and tourist feeding in the wild both significantly affected glucose metabolism, whereby iguanas exhibited a diabetic-like response. Overall, the physiological effects of the high sugar diet in laboratory-housed green iguanas were similar to those observed in tourist-fed populations of wild rock iguanas in the wild.

Finally, understanding the physiological consequences of human-induced diet shifts on wildlife to include the role that an altered microbiome plays provides critical insight.  A greater understanding of the long-term impacts of ecotourism will be especially important for managing threatened species. In addition to gaining these insights, we engaged graduate and undergraduate students in research to help develop the skills and confidence for a future generation of scientists. We also initiated a collaboration via a laboratory and field studies course at The University of The Bahamas that was concurrent with our field work and will build a local interest in monitoring impacts of ecotourism. Results and outcomes of this work will be incorporated into Shedd Aquarium Educational programs and media, and we engaged the press regarding our work that resulted from this grant.
